interactivity.to_get_this_event: Input the name of =) as the username in the rectangle during There is Nothing . Autoplays after " There is Nothing " , the event that started the chain.
interactivity.to_miss_this_event: Complete There is Nothing before entering =)'s name. Replaced by A Time When Things Were Horrible .

progression.synopsis: In a time when things were happier, Maya is sitting in her usual spot, and is relaxed in Sensei's company. He tells her that he might be [redacted], which Maya agrees is serious. The world goes strange. Maya wants to talk about how baby finches are sometimes eaten by their parents if they aren't developing well enough. She says that she and Sensei would be the same if they ever had kids. She starts to say that baby finches might be able to get their revenge sometimes, but isn't sure it would work. Ami seems to be in the background. Maya says that male finches might kill baby finches "just so it can get them out of the nest" and mate again. Sensei has some numerical thoughts about memory versus dreams, which Maya finds distracting. Sensei mentions being watched, and Maya talks about the god with roots. They cycle back around and repeat themselves. Ami looks less happy now. Sensei says that he was in the middle of something, and Maya asks what could be more important than spending time with his girlfriend. Sensei says that she isn't his girlfriend, and never was. He leaves, and is once again looking at the cool rectangle machine .
trivia: The event will loop back at the rectangle, so you don't need to re-input stuff
Other than this event, some username will display tinfoil material without progressing the event... give it a try!

event_references.event_missed_name: A Time When Things Were Horrible

changelog: This Event was added in Update 0.11.

secret_information.description:
== Happy Event ==
This Event is a special event with a special trigger (check requirements). It may or may not contain non-English content.
The following translations are available:

translations.translation: it's hard for me to tell how much of this is real and how much is a dream.
Somewhere, deep down, this feels just like yesterday.
But the floating cars and mangled muscle masses before me tell me otherwise.
If this is a memory, it is not a happy one.
But chances are it's just a nightmare.
